awd_titl_txt: Expanding International Microdata Access: Linked German Survey and Administrative Data
awd_abstract_narration:
This project maintains and expands international data sharing between the German Institute for Employment Research (IAB) and US researchers.  The principle is to provide researchers with increased ease of access to confidential survey and administrative data while maintaining data security by establishing a secure connection between secure Research Data Centers or data enclaves which share comparable standards with regard to data and confidentiality protection.  The PIs have piloted this approach with the establishment of such a data enclave at the Michigan Center for the Demography of Aging at the Institute for Social Research at the University of Michigan.  This award builds on the pilot by supporting the continued operation of the Michigan enclave and the expansion to other locations in the US Research Data Center network, including locations at Cornell and the University of California, Berkeley.

The data sharing arrangement allows qualified researchers access to extremely rich German survey and administrative data.  The data can be linked, have a panel structure, and cover all firms and employees in Germany (including the former East Germany) from 1975 to the present.  These data will be used in cutting-edge statistical analyses that compare US and German labor markets, macroeconomic dynamics, international trade, and industrial organization.  The data are also useful for a wide range of methodological research.  The project also contributes to graduate education; the ease of access to the German data means that graduate students can practice advanced data analysis skills in a practical way.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
During its lifetime, this project facilitated access to linked survey and administrative data from the German Federal Employment Agency (IAB) in a number of ways.  Several hundred researchers accessed and analyzed these data remotely, working in secure computing facilities (virtual enclaves) across the US, including dozens of graduate students who used the data for their dissertations, and resulting in dozens of journal publications.  The project increased the number of virtual enclaves in the US where researchers could access these data from one (Ann Arbor) to six (Ann Arbor, Los Angeles, Berkeley, Cambridge, Princeton, and Ithaca). It hosted a workshop of data users in Ann Arbor where 35 researchers presented their research, met with staff from the IAB, and listened to a keynote address from one of the most prominent labor economists in the world on how these data are changing labor economics.  The project produced documentation and metadata to make the data more usable, as well as guides for a number of datasets, particularly where information about the German law and the operation of its social security system was critical to understanding the administrative data being analyzed.  The project provided support to all US researchers using these data in applying for access, completing Institutional Review Board (IRB) applications, restricted data contracts.  It also provided user support in both the technical and substantive issues that arose during research projects and disclosure avoidance (confidentiality protection) review of researcher output.  The project worked to build a community of researchers using these data so that they could learn from one another, collaborate in research efforts, and organize presentations of their research at multiple venues.  Intellectual Merit: The project aimed to increase access to and use of German administrative data by economic, social and behavioral scientists in the U.S. in order to improve understanding of the functioning and changes over time of labor markets, including issues such as the impact of retirement, family, and tax policies, immigration, labor market regulations, and labor market integration, as well as entrepreneurship and innovation, trade, and the impact of the Great Recession on economic outcomes and efficiency.  Research on all of these topics was enabled and undertaken.  Broader Impact: Significant scientific output on topics such as the impact of retirement, family, and tax policies, immigration, labor market regulations, and labor market integration, as well as entrepreneurship and innovation, trade, and the impact of the Great Recession on economic outcomes and efficiency was produced.  Doctoral students in economics, sociology, and other fields were trained in the use of administrative data, confidentiality protection, and produced dissertations contributing to our understanding of the subjects listed above.

 


Last Modified: 03/14/2017
Modified by: Margaret Levenstein
